instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.USBC_XA_CC2: What is USBC_XA_CC2? USBC_XA_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> With a power cycle issue
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that when plugged in jumps from 5v to 20v and pulls up to 1.8a but then reboots the charger back to 0.2a. The screen shows the battery and then goes off again when the charger drops back to 0.2a

Does this on all 4 ports.

I've checked <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, UB300, UB400 and the main issue I can see is the following:

UB400 <SIGNAL>USBC_TB_CC1</SIGNAL> I only get 0.080v 
UB300 <SIGNAL>USBC_TA_CC2</SIGNAL> I only get 0.132v
<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> <SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC2</SIGNAL> I only get 0.004v

All others test as about 0.520v in diode mode.

So do you think there's a chance UB400, UB300 and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> need replacing or am I not looking far enough into this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> With a power cycle issue
threads.message:
CC1/2 lines get different voltage, depending on the connection sense.
Keep in mind, USB-C port has 2 connection ways possible; the detection is done with CC1/2 lines.

Is the battery charging?
If not, get a charged battery and test machine again.
Be sure to use 87W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> With a power cycle issue
threads.message:
Yeah works on 2 ports with an 87w charger. Hadn't noticed the one I was testing with was a 61w version.

On one of the ports its fine with the USBC plug turned upside down but not the other orientation.
On another port, I get 5v only with the plug one way round and 0v the other way.

I've tried 3 IO boards and all three do the same thing.

At least its powering on with two ports though

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> With a power cycle issue
threads.message: Compare diode mode readings on CC1/2 lines between all 4 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
